Group Details.Description: OilRigis a suspected Iranian threat group that has targeted Middle Eastern and international victims since at least 2014. The group has targeted a variety of sectors, including financial, government, energy, chemical, and telecommunications. It appears the group carries out supply chain attacks, leveraging the trust relationship between organizations to attack their primary targets. The group works on behalf of the Iranian government based on infrastructure details that contain references to Iran, use of Iranian infrastructure, and targeting that aligns with nation-state interests.[1][2][3][4][5][6][7]

Associated Groups.Name: APT34
Associated Groups.Description: This group was previously tracked under two distinct groups, APT34 and OilRig, but was combined due to additional reporting giving higher confidence about the overlap of the activity.[7][1][10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Account Discovery: Local Account
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has run net user, net user /domain, net group "domain admins" /domain, and net group "Exchange Trusted Subsystem" /domain to get account listings on a victim.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Account Discovery: Domain Account
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has run net user, net user /domain, net group "domain admins" /domain, and net group "Exchange Trusted Subsystem" /domain to get account listings on a victim.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Application Layer Protocol: Web Protocols
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used HTTP for C2.[6][12][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Application Layer Protocol: DNS
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used DNS for C2 including the publicly available requestbin.net tunneling service.[6][12][13][10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Automated Collection
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used automated collection.[6]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Brute Force
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used brute force techniques to obtain credentials.[12]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used various types of scripting for execution.[1][14][15][7][16]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: PowerShell
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used PowerShell scripts for execution, including use of a macro to run a PowerShell command to decode file contents.[1][17][9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Windows Command Shell
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used macros to deliver malware such as QUADAGENT and OopsIE.[1][14][15][7][16] OilRig has used batch scripts.[1][14][15][7][16]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Visual Basic
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used VBScript macros for execution on compromised hosts.[10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Credentials from Password Stores
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[6][12][18][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Credentials from Web Browsers
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[6][12][18][13] OilRig has also used tool named PICKPOCKET to dump passwords from web browsers.[13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Windows Credential Manager
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used credential dumping tool named VALUEVAULT to steal credentials from the Windows Credential Manager.[13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Deobfuscate/Decode Files or Information
Tactics and Techniques.Use: A OilRig macro has run a PowerShell command to decode file contents. OilRig has also used certutil to decode base64-encoded files on victims.[1][17][15][19]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Encrypted Channel: Asymmetric Cryptography
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.[12]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol: Exfiltration Over Unencrypted Non-C2 Protocol
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has exfiltrated data over FTP separately from its primary C2 channel over DNS.[5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: External Remote Services
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig uses remote services such as VPN, Citrix, or OWA to persist in an environment.[12]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Fallback Channels
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig malware ISMAgent falls back to its DNS tunneling mechanism if it is unable to reach the C2 server over HTTP.[14]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Indicator Removal: File Deletion
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has deleted files associated with their payload after execution.[1][15]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Ingress Tool Transfer
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig can download remote files onto victims.[1]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Input Capture: Keylogging
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used keylogging tools called KEYPUNCH and LONGWATCH.[12][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Masquerading
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used .doc file extensions to mask malicious executables.[10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Network Service Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used the publicly available tool SoftPerfect Network Scanner as well as a custom tool called GOLDIRONY to conduct network scanning.[12]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Indicator Removal from Tools
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has tested malware samples to determine AV detection and subsequently modified the samples to ensure AV evasion.[2][16]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Obfuscated Files or Information: Encrypted/Encoded File
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has encrypted and encoded data in its malware, including by using base64.[1][7][6][9][16]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Office Application Startup: Outlook Home Page
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has abused the Outlook Home Page feature for persistence. OilRig has also used CVE-2017-11774 to roll back the initial patch designed to protect against Home Page abuse.[20]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: OS Credential Dumping: LSASS Memory
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as Mimikatz to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[6][12][18][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: OS Credential Dumping: LSA Secrets
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[6][12][18][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: OS Credential Dumping: Cached Domain Credentials
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[6][12][18][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Password Policy Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used net.exe in a script with net accounts /domain to find the password policy of a domain.[21]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Peripheral Device Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used tools to identify if a mouse is connected to a targeted system.[10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Permission Groups Discovery: Local Groups
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used net localgroup administrators to find local administrators on compromised systems.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Permission Groups Discovery: Domain Groups
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used net group /domain, net group "domain admins" /domain, and net group "Exchange Trusted Subsystem" /domain to find domain group permission settings.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Phishing: Spearphishing Attachment
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious attachments to potential victims using compromised and/or spoofed email accounts.[15][7][9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Phishing: Spearphishing Link
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has sent spearphising emails with malicious links to potential victims.[15]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Phishing: Spearphishing via Service
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used LinkedIn to send spearphishing links.[13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Process Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has run tasklist on a victim's machine.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Protocol Tunneling
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used the Plink utility and other tools to create tunnels to C2 servers.[6][12][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Query Registry
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used reg query "HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Terminal Server Client\Default" on a victim to query the Registry.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used Remote Desktop Protocol for lateral movement. The group has also used tunneling tools to tunnel RDP into the environment.[6][12][19]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Remote Services: SSH
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used Putty to access compromised systems.[6]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Scheduled Task/Job: Scheduled Task
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has created scheduled tasks that run a VBScript to execute a payload on victim machines.[15][7][13][10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Screen Capture
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has a tool called CANDYKING to capture a screenshot of user's desktop.[12]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Server Software Component: Web Shell
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used web shells, often to maintain access to a victim network.[6][12][19]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Binary Proxy Execution: Compiled HTML File
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used a CHM payload to load and execute another malicious file once delivered to a victim.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Information Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has run hostname and systeminfo on a victim.[4][5][13][10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Network Configuration Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has run ipconfig /all on a victim.[4][5]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Network Connections Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used netstat -an on a victim to get a listing of network connections.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Owner/User Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has run whoami on a victim.[4][5][10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: System Service Discovery
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used sc query on a victim to gather information about services.[4]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Unsecured Credentials: Credentials In Files
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used credential dumping tools such as LaZagne to steal credentials to accounts logged into the compromised system and to Outlook Web Access.[6][12][18][13]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: User Execution: Malicious Link
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has delivered malicious links to achieve execution on the target system.[15][7][9]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: User Execution: Malicious File
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has delivered macro-enabled documents that required targets to click the "enable content" button to execute the payload on the system.[15][7][9][10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Valid Accounts
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used compromised credentials to access other systems on a victim network.[6][12][19]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Virtualization/Sandbox Evasion: System Checks
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used macros to verify if a mouse is connected to a compromised machine.[10]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Windows Management Instrumentation
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has used WMI for execution.[12]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Drive-by Compromise
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has been seen utilizing watering hole attacks to collect credentials which could be used to gain access into ICS networks. https://www.cyberviser.com/2018/05/group-linked-to-shamoon-attacks-targeting-ics-networks-in-middle-east-and-uk/

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Scripting
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig has embedded a macro within spearphishing attachments that has been made up of both a VBScript and a PowerShell script.[23]

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Spearphishing Attachment
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig used spearphishing emails with malicious Microsoft Excel spreadsheet attachments. https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/the-oilrig-campaign-attacks-on-saudi-arabian-organizations-deliver-helminth-backdoor/

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Standard Application Layer Protocol
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig communicated with its command and control using HTTP requests. https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/the-oilrig-campaign-attacks-on-saudi-arabian-organizations-deliver-helminth-backdoor/

Tactics and Techniques.Name: Valid Accounts
Tactics and Techniques.Use: OilRig utilized stolen credentials to gain access to victim machines.[24]
